 CONTRIBUTION OF LITERATURE IN SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT  
Dr. Uttam Ramchandra Patil  
Professor & Head,  Department of English,  
Rajarshi Shahu Arts & Commerce College, Rukadi,  
Tal. Hatkanangale, Dist. Kolhapur (MS) INDIA  
Email:  uttamnayana@gmail.com  
ABSTRACT  
This paper is an attempt to explore the contribution of literature in promoting sustainable 
development. Various literary works are critically analysed to examine how literature can raise awareness 
about environmental issues, promote social justice, gender  equity and inspire individual and collective action 
towards sustainability. Literature can be considered as the mother of all knowledge. It is made of the life 
experiences. It has the power to shape our perceptions, values, and behaviors.  The United Nati ons have 
framed 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Literature can play a crucial role in attaining these goals as 
literature is closely related to culture. And both literature and culture are connected to sustainability. By 
investigating the connecti ons between literature, culture, and sustainability, this paper exhibits the potential of 
literature to contribute to a more equitable and environmentally conscious world.  
KEYWORDS : literature,  Sustainable Development Goals, environment, social justice, ge nder equity.  
INTRODUCTION  
Literature is a purely human phenomenon. It is a means by which human beings present their 
experiences, thoughts, ideas, emotions and feelings. Literature is about life and the people in relation to the 
social, cultural, economic, political, environmental,  and all the other aspects of life. It is about interpersonal as 
well as intrapersonal relations. It aims to entertain and educate the readers. Literature educates people by 
making them aware about various glocal issues. The modern world has emerged with h uge rapid materialistic 
development which has been drastically affecting the environment al, social and economic human balance. To 
attain development the natural resources are being exploited to an extreme level that may damage the harmony 
of over -all life on the globe. That is why the UNO have been putting efforts to make development sustainable. 
Literature is the mirror of life. It presents the pressing issues of the society and tries to provide solutions to 
them. No doubt, literature is fictitious but it is very useful for enlightenment and awakening of people.  There 
are plenty of literary works across all the genres that highlight the sustainable development goals and make 
readers aware of the serious problems which have incurred due to materialistic deve lopment. Some literary 
works discuss the influence of development on environmental, social and economic aspects of life.    
Sustainable development is a pressing global issue, requiring immediate attention and action. The 
United Nations' SDGs highlight the need for a holistic approach to sustainability, encompassing 
environmental, social, and economic dimensions. Literature, as a powerful tool for shaping cultural narratives 
and influencing individual and collective behaviors, has a significant role to play in promoting sustainable 
development.  
Sustainable development is a method to satisfy needs of the people today without depriving future 
generations of their needs. It is an approach that balances diverse requirements against the consciousness of the 
enviro nmental, economic and social limitations that a society has. According to Our Common Future  which is 
also known as Brundtland Report , ‘Sustainable  development  is development  that meets  the needs  of the 
present  without  compromising  the ability  of future  generations  to meet  their own needs .’1 
Today’s world has grave environmental challenges like climate change, freshwater exhaustion, 
deforestation, air and water pollution, and hunger. Natural resources are either running out or are being 
polluted due to th e rapid and huge development. There is a need to utilize the earth’s resources sensibly and

 preserve and conserve them for the future generations. Sustainable development emphasizes the improvement 
of human -environment interaction through prioritization of the management and protection of the natural 
resources for coming generations. Through the conservation and enhancement of our natural resources all the 
nations can satisfy the basic needs of employment, food, water, energy and sanitation. The natural resources 
can be conserved and enhanced by promoting stable economic growth, conservation of natural resources, 
environmental protection, social progress and equality.  
Further, sustainable development is an attitude to development. It considers various necessities against 
an awareness of the environmental, social and economic limitations a society faces.  It propagates the social 
responsibility to use the natural resources wisely and sensibly so that the balance of the nature is not disturbed. 
To attain this , in September, 2015 the countries under the UNO adopted 17 sustainable development goals. 
These goals are  – 1. No poverty, 2. Zero hunger, 3. Good health and w ell-being, 4. Quality education, 5. 
Gender equality, 6. Clean water and sanitation, 7. Affordable and clean energy, 8. Decent work and economic 
growth, 9. Industry innovation and infrastruc ture, 10. Reduced inequalities, 11. Sustainable cities and 
communities, 12. Responsible consumption and production, 13. Climate action, 14. Life below water, 15. Life 
on land, 16. Peace, justice and strong institutions, and 17. Partnerships for the goals.  The sustainability has the 
three pillars , namely, environmental sustainability, social sustainabilit y, and economic sustainability which 
cover all the goals of sustainable development. They are interconnected. Literature has proved to be an 
effective means  of promotion of matters in the society.  It has been used to promote all the above mentioned 
sustainable development goals. Out of the seventeen sustainable development goals literature primarily 
promotes the SDGs like – no poverty, zero hunger, quality ed ucation, gender equality, reduced inequalities, 
sustainable cities and communities, peace and justice by pointing out their actual state as prevailed in the 
society. The present paper is a humble attempt to consider the contribution of literature in attain ing sustainable 
development.  
Contribution of Literature in Creating Environmental Awareness:  
Literature is a powerful means of creating environmental awareness . It has long been used to raise 
awareness about environment. Literary works like  Rachel Carson ’s “Silent Spring” (1962), Margaret 
Atwood’s “The Year of the Flood” (2009), Prabhakar Pendarkar’s “Rarang Dhang” ( 1981 ) and Dilip Chitre’s 
“Felling of the Banyan Tree” ( 1980 ) have highlighted the devastating impacts of human activities on the 
natural worl d. Even the contemporary English novels like Vander  Meer’s “Annihilation” (2014) and Claire 
Vaye Watkins’ “Gold Fame Citrus” (2015) continue to explore and alarm the consequences of environmental 
degradation.  
Let us see some details about “Felling of the Banyan Tree” a  famous poem by Dilip Chitre  who was a 
respected and versatile Indian artist. He was a popular poet. He wrote in both English and Marathi.  “Felling of 
the Banyan Tree” was first published in Chitre’s collection of poems entitled, Traveling i n a Cage  in 1980. It 
is a free verse poem consisting of three stanzas, wi th in all twenty five lines. It s central theme is uprootedness 
of modern human beings. The secondary theme of the poem is the destruction of ecosystems for monetary gain 
in the name o f progress and its impact on environment and human life.  
The persona tells that his father asked all the tenants to vacate their houses so that the houses could  be 
demolished. Then all the houses except one in which the persona’s family lived were destroyed. The persona’s 
father ord ered to fell the trees there. Then all the tre es like neem, sheoga, audumbar, and others were cut down. 
The persona’s grandmother suggested not to fell the trees as they are sacred and felling them is a crime but the 
father did not listen to her and all the trees were massacred. The word, massacre shows the beingness of trees. 
But felling the enormous banyan tree was a big problem as it was thrice the size of the persona’s house. The 
circumference of its trunk was about fi fty feet. Its aerial roots were thirty feet long and they touched the 
ground. It was the house for multitude of insects and birds. But the father ordered to cut the banyan tree down.

 The insects and birds were disturbed. In a way the ecosystem was disturbe d. It took fifty men to fell the banyan 
tree whose slaughter was fearsome and fascinating. Soon after that the persona’s family moved to Bombay  
where there were not many trees. And the persona could see the tree in dreams only.  
The poem creates environmen tal awareness. It shows the difference between the serene and 
satisfactory greenery of trees and the jungle of cement concrete buildings. And it points out that if the trees are 
cut down in this way the future generations will have to see the trees only in  dreams. The poem promotes the 
sustainable development  from the environmental dimension .   
Contribution of Literature in Promoting Social Justice:  
Literature has two goals: to entertain and to educate. In some cases literature has been the cause of 
social revolutions e rupted to attain social justice which is a key dimension of sustainable development. 
Literary works such as Neale Hurston’s “Their Eyes were Watching God” (1937) and Chinua Achebe’s 
“Things Fall Apart” (1958) have focused the life of marginali zed communities. Similarly, works of Mulk Raj 
Anand promote social justice for the downtrodden people and communities in the Indian society. His novel 
“Untouchable”  (1981)  presents the miserable life of the untouchable and provides the possible solutions t o the 
problem of untouchability. The argument for eradicating the caste system is at the centre of the novel. It 
presents a day in the life of a young sweeper boy, Bakha whose work is to clean latrines. The same is promoted 
by Omprakash Valmiki in his poem, “What would you do?”  (2008).  
Similarly, the recent novel , “Foreign” (2013)  by Sonara Jha is the projection of the plight of farmers in 
Vidarbha, India.  The novel discusses the haplessness of the farmers, their desperation and depression, the 
indiffe rence of government, selfishness of moneylenders, corrupt government officers, and the farmers’ 
protest. The novel successfully publicizes the agonies and plight of hapless farmers in India. Jha makes Indian 
farmers’ suicides a global concern.  
Contributio n of Literature in Promoting Gender Equity:  
In the male -dominated society, woman is always victim ized. She is brought up in such a way that she 
accepts that she is born to suffer and serve the man. Literature has been exploring the life of women and their 
miseri es to the world and promoting gender equity so as to give justice to women. For instance, Arun 
Kolatkar’s portrayal of woman in his poem ‘Woman’ (2004) is as per the existing reality in the society. 
Selflessness is cultivated in the woman to serve th e selfishness in the man. This radical poem protests against 
the injustice, oppression, and exploitation done to the woman in the cruel and crafty male -dominated culture. 
Similarly, Kishor Kale in his autobiography, Against All Odds (2000) presents  the  st ories of Kolhati women 
and shows that their life is tied with ghungroos  of the rich lusty men who want just to use them and throw 
them away like a cheap object. The book brought a kind of reformation in the Kolhati women and many of 
them started taking edu cation and change their hellish life.  
CONCLUSION:  
To conclude, literature has a vital role to play in promoting sustainable development. It can raise 
awareness about en vironmental issues. It is an effective tool to promote social justice and gender equity. It can 
contribute to a more equitable and environmentally conscious world. As the world contends  with the 
challenges of sustainability, literature can serve as a power ful tool for shaping cultural narratives and 
influencing individual and collective behaviours.
